prompt_init: You will receive a text. Your task is to rephrase this text without modifying its meaning. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
prompt_update: You will receive a text. Your task is to rephrase this text without modifying its meaning. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
initial_story:
The winner of a Xiangqi, or Chinese chess, tournament has been stripped of his title after allegations of inappropriate behaviour.

Yan Chenglong has also been accused of cheating by using a communication device analogous to anal beads.

The 48-year-old has been stripped of his title and banned from playing for a year.

However, the Chinese Xiangqi Association (CXA) says it's impossible to prove accusations of cheating.

Xiangqi has been hugely popular across Asia for hundreds of years.

According to the CXA, Mr Yan started drinking with friends in his hotel room shortly after winning the title of "Xiangqi King" at a national tournament held on the Chinese island of Hainan last week.

He then defecated in the hotel bath in an act "that damaged hotel property and violated public order and good morals", said the CXA statement.

The CXA was forced to address rumours circulating online that Mr Yan had cheated using anal beads equipped with wireless transmitters to send and receive signals.

"Based on our understanding of the situation, it is currently impossible to prove that Yan engaged in cheating via 'anal beads' as speculated on social media," the CXA said.

As punishment for bad behaviour, Mr Yan was stripped of his title and banned from playing for a year.

The association did not disclose the amount of prize money Yan was forfeiting, but Xiangqi tournaments often promise winners tens of thousands of yuan (thousands of dollars), according to AFP.
stories:
A Chinese chess champion has been stripped of his title and banned from competition for a year due to allegations of inappropriate behavior.

Yan Chenglong, 48, was accused of cheating during a national tournament on the island of Hainan by using a wireless communication device, with some speculating that it was hidden in anal beads.

Although the Chinese Xiangqi Association (CXA) could not prove the cheating allegations, Yan was penalized for his behavior in his hotel room after winning the title, including defecating in the bathtub, which caused property damage and disturbed public order.

As a result, Yan's title of "Xiangqi King" was revoked, and he is barred from playing for a year. The amount of prize money he forfeits was not disclosed, but winners of Xiangqi tournaments often receive tens of thousands of yuan.

Xiangqi, a popular game in Asia for centuries, has been marred by this scandal, which began with rumors circulating online about Yan's alleged cheating methods.

A Chinese chess master has lost his championship title and faces a one-year competition ban amid allegations of misconduct. 

Yan Chenglong, 48, was suspected of cheating during a national tournament on Hainan Island by using a wireless device, with some speculation that it was concealed in an unusual object. 

Although the Chinese Xiangqi Association (CXA) was unable to substantiate the cheating claims, Yan was punished for his behavior in his hotel room following his win, including an incident involving defecation in the bathtub that caused property damage and a public disturbance.

As a consequence, Yan's "Xiangqi King" title was revoked, and he is prohibited from competing for a year. The amount of prize money he must forfeit remains undisclosed, but Xiangqi tournament winners often receive tens of thousands of yuan.

This scandal has tarnished the reputation of Xiangqi, a centuries-old popular game in Asia, which began with online rumors circulating about Yan's alleged cheating methods.

However, Yan's behavior in his hotel room following his win, including an incident involving defecation in the bathtub that resulted in property damage and a public disturbance, led to his punishment. 

As a result, Yan's "Xiangqi King" title was revoked, and he is barred from competing for a year. Additionally, he will have to forfeit an undisclosed amount of prize money, which is often in the tens of thousands of yuan for Xiangqi tournament winners. 

This scandal has damaged the reputation of Xiangqi, a centuries-old popular game in Asia, which began with online rumors circulating about Yan's alleged cheating methods.

A prominent 48-year-old Xiangqi grandmaster, Yan Chengong, has faced severe penalties, including a year-long competition ban and the removal of his prestigious "Xiangqi King" title, due to allegations of unfair play. Although no concrete proof exists to confirm the use of a hidden wireless device to cheat during a national tournament on Hainan Island, his suspicious behavior in his hotel room after winning ultimately led to his downfall. As a result, Yan is prohibited from competing for a year, must forfeit a prize worth tens of thousands of yuan, and has tarnished the reputation of Xiangqi, a revered Asian game already troubled by online rumors about his alleged cheating tactics.
